subtitle: We have just released issue 4 of the New Thinking Allowed magazine.
Download it for free at newthinkingallowed.org.
New Thinking Allowed is a non-profit endeavor.
Your contributions to the New Thinking Allowed Foundation
make a meaningful difference in our ability to produce new videos.
Hello, I'm Christopher Naughton, and I'm happy to be working alongside
long-time host Jeffrey Mishlove and co-host Emmy Vadnais.
Quick note at the top, please hit like, subscribe, comment, ring the bell,
and help other people like you find programs like these.
Well, this is the Gimbal footage, a video released by the United States government
and its Department of Defense from footage
procured from the USS Carrier Theodore Roosevelt
back in 2015.
My guest today is Matthew Roberts, a former
naval cryptologist who was aboard the Roosevelt,
who actually reviewed the Gimbal event and later the Go Fast event as well.
He tells us how it dramatically impacted his life.
He also says the United States government has more footage like this, a lot more.
In 2020, after the Gimbal event and after
the New York Times 2017 article regarding it,
Matthew wrote this book, Initiated, in which
he tells intimate details of what happened
in his life, both positive and harrowing, in light of the Gimbal event.
He also has been part of the four-part
Encounter series, which has aired on Netflix.
Matthew joins us from Tempe, Arizona today.
Thank you for joining us today.
I appreciate you coming here and joining us on New Thinking Allowed.
So you're one of the first interviews that we see in the Encounter series,
which again is aired on Netflix, produced by Spielberg and Amblin Entertainment.
And in this clip, we're going to show our audience.
You not only describe the Gimbal event, but you also describe its frequency.
My name is Matthew Roberts.
I was a cryptologic technician in the U.S. Navy for 16 years.
I was present on the USS Theodore Roosevelt for the Gimbal event.
So that was the first time I saw the Gimbal footage.
I was watching this footage and I could see no kind of aviation surfaces that you would
expect to see, wings, tail, you know, rudder, there's none of that.
I knew that it wasn't ours, right?
I knew that it wasn't anybody else's.
So, I mean, that only leaves the Gimbal.
So, I mean, that only leaves one other option, I think.
Which is what?
And that's non-human tech, non-human intelligence technology.
This was not a one-off event for the Navy.
These things happen frequently.
All the time.
They happen all the time.
So, did it happen all the time?
Was this a frequent event aboard the carrier that you were on?
Yeah, yeah, they do happen all the time.
And I can tell you that not only did this happen during our workup cycle,
but later when we were on deployment and we were what they call on-station in the Gulf,
we had them come back.
They showed up again.
Was that the GoFast event or was that something else yet again?
So, both the Gimbal and the GoFast event,
those videos were both from our workup cycle.
And so, those objects came back again when we were on station.
But as I said, they happen all the time.
They happen to other carrier groups.
This wasn't specific to us.
And these are the F-18s flying off your carrier that are capturing this footage.
It's not as if guys on the ship, sailors on the ship, were seeing UFOs or were they?
Well, I hesitate to go any further than that.
The thing that I will say is that they happen
frequently, and that's what I'll say about it.
I understand.
I know there are certain things you can and cannot say.
But what I do understand is that you have 5,000 sailors on this ship,
and you said that it really wasn't common knowledge, at least the Gimbal event
wasn't common knowledge to most of the people on that ship.
That's correct.
Yeah.
The regular people on the ship that aren't read in, that don't have a clearance,
that aren't in Intel.
So, if you weren't in Intel or the air wing,
the likelihood was that you would not know that anything was going on.
So, the ship wasn't a buzz with this.
There were only certain people who were
talking about it who knew what was happening.
So, how did you find out about it?
I mean, as I recall, one of the stories you
tell is like they started talking about UFOs,
someone started talking about UFOs, and you
almost didn't want to hear their conversation.
Yes, that is true, but that wasn't the first time I heard about it.
So, the first time I heard about it, one of my
buddies who works more closely with the air wing
came into the SCIF where I work, and he said,
hey, I've got something to show you, you know?
And so, I sat down at my computer and I pulled it up,
and we all kind of just gathered around the computer and watched these clips.
And so, that was the first time I saw it.
And later, of course, I heard I was going to a meeting,
I heard there were two pilots standing on either side of the briefing room door,
and they were talking about, hey, did you see the UFOs, the videos?
And they were just discussing it, and I kind
of threw my head down at the floor and just
walked right past them.
I didn't want to hear that conversation, you know?
It may be part of recurring theme, which we're going to address today,
is that sometimes people just don't want to hear some of these things.
Maybe that's what you were going through.
Because didn't you say that you had an emotional reaction to this
when you were examining the footage?
Yes, I did.
And I didn't understand it at the time, but I kind of, I did.
I had a very emotional reaction to it.
I could kind of feel tears welling up in my eyes as I'm watching this footage.
And I didn't understand it, and I watched the footage obsessively,
you know, for the next several months.
To the point that people would come into the shop where I work,
and they saw it, they would see me watching it again,
and they're like, oh, are you watching that again?
You know, what is wrong with you?
And I would just say, how do you not think this
is the most incredible thing you've ever seen?
It reminds me of that scene in Close Encounters where Richard Dreyfuss,
once he's seen the event, he has to look at it over and over again.
He becomes obsessed in some ways.
I'm not saying that this is a one-on-one with you,
but in some ways that is part of the obsession, right?
This is so otherworldly, so important, so galvanizing
that you can't look away once you do start looking.
Yes, absolutely.
I would say that the people who made Close Encounters
knew that about this subject, and so the character
that Richard Dreyfuss plays resembles a lot of
people who end up looking into this.
It becomes an obsession, you know, and you just can't take yourself away from it.
And of course, many of those people have secondary and tertiary encounters,
and we're going to get into that to your personal story as well.
But what I have to say, you know, that you have also said that you don't believe
that this is the only footage that the United States government has.
And I know, again, recently, Congress, I don't want to say has been forced,
but maybe their hand has been pushed to the
point that they had to release some footage.
But you say there's a lot more, and it's a lot more definitive.
Yes.
To the degree you can divulge this.
I understand you're under some restrictions, even though you retired Navy.
Nevertheless, you have gone on the record by saying
you wish they'd show some of the more definitive footage.
Yeah, I mean, there are things out there that if the public were to see it,
there'd be no doubt as to what this is.
I know it's interesting because what you demonstrate, again, in the Gimbal footage,
it's still pretty mind bending.
And it still is something that, as you describe in that clip,
no rudders, no tails, no exhaust, no nothing.
So that still seems pretty convincing.
But I guess what you're saying is there's even more convincing definitive evidence
that if I were to see it or my colleagues were to see it, we'd say, OK, no doubt.
Yes, absolutely.
I mean, because the footage that has been released thus far,
a lot of it is just very ambiguous, right?
You look at it and you say, well, that could be a balloon.
It could be a piece of floating debris.
But if you were to see it moving in some anomalous way,
some way that aircraft don't move, which these things certainly exist.
So if you were to see that, it would kind of take away that ambiguity.
So when the crew, or at least the people you're working with on the Roosevelt,
start to discover this footage, is it business as usual?
Or do some people start getting attached to it like you had?
For everyone else, it was just kind of business as usual.
Every once in a while, someone would bring it up and we would start talking about it.
But for the most part, everyone just kind of put it away.
But you pursued it in 2015, is when this occurs.
And by 2017, the New York Times now starts to divulge some of the information,
some of the information that had been, let's face it, let's just speak frankly,
had been hidden, top secret, classified for years.
Yes, absolutely.
And with that article, they released the Gimbal footage and also footage from the
Nimitz incident off the west coast of the United States.
Right. But there's more to come.
Yeah, hopefully.
Well, you would think inevitably a lot more of this is going to come out,
even though it's been so many years.
I just have to show you this quick clip because we went back and did some research.
And this is a quick Department of Defense clip from 1950.
And this is a clip from the New York Times.
This is a quick Department of Defense clip from 1952.
And it's basically two people high up on the
chain with slightly different opinions of
UFOs and UAPs.
Let's take a look.
I am here to discuss the so-called flying saucers.
The Air Force interest in this problem has been due to our feeling of an obligation to
identify and analyze to the best of our ability anything in the air
that may have the possibility of threat or menace to the United States.
In pursuit of this obligation since 1947, we have received and analyzed between one
and two thousand reports that have come to us from all kinds of sources.
Of this great mass of reports, we have been able
adequately to explain the great bulk of them.
However, there have been a certain percentage
of this volume of reports that have been made by
credible observers of relatively incredible things.
With all due respect to the Air Force, I
believe that some of them will prove to be of
interplanetary origin.
During a three-year investigation, I found that
many pilots have described objects of substance
and high speed.
One case, pilots reported their plane was buffeted by an object which passed them at
500 miles an hour.
Obviously, this was a solid object and I believe it was from outer space.
So looking at that footage, Matthew, you know, you get the idea.
One general is saying most of this can be explained.
Some of it can't be.
Then Major Keyhoe, who wrote a book, just put
it out there, you know, UFOs are real, says,
no, this stuff is absolutely valid.
That's kind of a fight, a conflict that we have seen now for what, 70 years.
Yeah, and it's still ongoing.
I mean, if you listen to recent comments of higher ranking people, you'll have some of
them saying, you know, a lot of this is just
airborne clutter and, you know, it's balloons,
it's garbage floating in the air, it's a plastic bag floating in the wind.
And you have others who are saying the opposite.
I think, though, the truth is somewhere in between.
I'm sure there are things that are balloons that have gotten loose, research balloons.
You know, and airborne clutter.
But there are other things as well that are up
there that do not behave like a balloon or clutter.
Yeah, I mean, in this clip that I showed you from DOD in 1952, this was late July.
This is only weeks after numerous UFOs, as we
called them at the time, buzzed the White House.
Not once, but twice.
You were probably aware of that at some point in time.
At some point in time, you became aware of those historic buzzings.
Did you not?
Yeah, and, you know, there's a whole UFO cluster.
When was that?
Was that back in the 50s?
Yeah, and, you know, they wanted to say that that was just atmospheric phenomenon.
Nothing to see here, you know, but I don't know.
I just, of course, I don't buy it, you know, if
there were some kind of atmospheric phenomenon
that were causing these things to materialize,
I think it would be common knowledge.
Pilots would see that all the time and they would know what it is, you know.
Right, and here pilots were seeing craft that were moving, you know, several times
their speed and making right-hand turns and stops and goes and that sort of thing.
Balloons just don't do that.
So, what I find interesting about the Encounter series is that, to me,
it's a story of vindication because we've known for decades good, upstanding people,
not only sober, temperate-minded people in the
military, level-headed people such as yourself.
We're seeing pillars of communities and I love the way they started this out.
One of the gentlemen from Stevensville, Texas,
he's an entrepreneur, he's a pilot himself.
He's up on a hill with two other buddies.
He's castigated.
He's basically pushed to the side and this has been the recurring story, right?
That's correct and, you know, that's one of the
reasons why I came forward with my own story
because I didn't like the idea that this was
being kept secret and that people were being
ostracized in this way unnecessarily.
That just didn't sit okay with me and, especially, you have people in careers who
maybe their career is dependent upon their psychological state, you know?
And so, if you go to that, if you start talking about this stuff and maybe your
wife wants you to go to a psychiatrist or your
spouse and they diagnose you with something like
schizophrenia or some other possibly career-ending
diagnosis, I'm just not okay with that.
I'm not okay with that at all.
It's wrong.
It's disgusting that that is allowed to continue.
That was really one of my biggest driving forces that I did not like
the fact that that is out there and that is happening.
Yeah, and this seems to be common over and over
again and that's why I think the Encounter series,
you know, by Amblin Entertainment is a vindication
story because it tells the stories of people,
good people, kids, teachers, businessmen, military people.
Again, not the kind of person, not some crazed
sternal bun sitting on the corner somewhere.
These people are pillars of society and, of course, also I found
really captivating the first story with Eddy Weiss
who is a former a member of Homeland Security.
He's talking to his kids like this stuff is real kids and he's using the Bible.
And I will say too that, you know, there are a
lot of people out there who have theories about
what this is and something that I came to understand in my own experiences was that
this experience that I had was what kind of gave birth to all the world's religions.
So the fact that he's using the Bible in these descriptions and using the Bible as,
as, hey, you know, this is what this is, you know, I don't view that as really
out there. I think that there's more truth to
that than people would be comfortable with.
Certainly most atheists, which is how you grew up, right?
Yeah, absolutely. I mean, you know, when I was when all of this was happening to me,
I was a devout atheist. I did not believe in any
of this. I thought it was a bunch of hocus pocus.
I this is and the answers that I came to
ultimately were not the answers that I wanted.
Actually, I very much resisted that throughout
the entire experience. I just said to myself,
you know, I things would come up and I would
say, no, that is that is not what this is,
you know, and I resisted it very much. But in the
end, I kind of the proof just became so much that
I could not deny I couldn't deny it any longer.
And, you know, and I want to get into we're going
to get more deeply into your own personal story,
Matthew, because I think that's the linchpin
here. But since, you know, we've touched on the
notion of people not being believed. And that's
one of the reasons that we find ourselves 70 some
years after the initial some of the initial sightings, the government admitting them in
the late 1940s while we're still in this place
of conflict and why there have been so many
casualties. You know, the most compelling story
I felt in the entire Encounter series was a story
out of Zimbabwe where 62 young children, black
students, white students are basically testifying
to the fact that they saw an alien craft land that
aliens stepped out of the ship. And let me play a
little bit of a clip here because this is these
are some of the people who were again castigated,
kicked to the curb, not believe told they were
crazy. You kids aren't don't know what you're
seeing. You have a vivid imagination and encounters
went back and interviewed these so called kids.
Now they're adults. Of course, this is 30 years
on. And here's what some of them had to say.
I saw a little object hovering. It was quite
big, actually. And then there was little ones
all rounded. And it looked as if they were
changing spaceships, silver, shiny disk with
lights on the lower half of the door lights. It was like, [clicking sounds]
And I saw like a door. And then suddenly he was
over there. And he was right in front of us.
I blinked. And then I saw the being less than like a meter or two away from me.
I believe in it because I did see it.
This is a story that we're sharing. This is a
story that we're proud of. This is a story that
if you want to talk about it, talk about it. If you don't want to talk about it,
don't talk about it. But it's your story as
well. This is a very important story to tell,
but not so much because of the incident itself.
It's an important human story to tell, to simply
say humans have experienced this. Yeah, I, you
know, I think it's unfortunate that there are,
there are these things that happen where people,
they don't want to believe that this is happening.
And I come across this still, even today,
people say, oh, you know, you're a liar. But,
you know, the footage is there. And why not
believe people? Why are we so willing to just
throw away what someone says they saw just
because we don't want to believe it personally?
That's, that's the thing. And I think the reason people do that is because
in order to do that, in order to admit, okay, maybe these people did see something,
right? Then, then you have to start to admit to
yourself that, well, maybe there's more going on
here than I realize. And that's, that's a very,
that puts you in a very uncomfortable position
because this, this is not something that currently
fits your worldview. And so if you're going to be
sympathetic with this person and say, okay, maybe
you saw something that, that, that starts to
mess with your own kind of mental stability in a way that makes you uncomfortable.
And understanding of reality.
Yes, exactly. It will shake your worldview.
You know, what I found really, again, another
compelling aspect to this, to this really amazing
series Encounters is John Mack, a heralded Harvard
psychiatrist, not only, not only is he heralded
for what he did, he was a Pulitzer Prize winner.
He headed up the department, the psychiatry
department at Harvard. He was a pioneer in child
psychiatry. He started to seriously listen to
these people who claimed that they had had abduction experiences, alien experiences,
close encounters of first, second, third, et cetera, kind. He goes over to Zimbabwe
and the kids say he was the only one that we
really trusted. And yet John Mack, you know,
was thrown under the bus as well. He was the only
professor at Harvard ever where they tried to take
his tenure away. There, there are still some
people who watch Encounters though, and they,
they kind of, you know, push it away. They, they don't want to think about this, but I,
you know, I think it is a vindication story because you've got people like myself,
people who are credible, people who had, you
have people who have had clearances for years
and decades now out there talking about these
things as though they're real because they are real.
And I think that these people who have been
suffering for so long should feel vindicated
and they should feel good about it. And they
should be proud of what, what happened there
at that school that day. And they should let anyone tell them otherwise, you know.
Yeah, there was one person there that day who said
it was all made up, but he doesn't come across
nearly as credible in the story as do these innocent kids, these, these kids who are,
you can just look in their face and you know,
there doesn't seem to be a, a hint of guile
in their eyes. They're just basically reporting, you know, what they've seen.
Now you've hit on a point and Kevin Knuth, who's
a former NASA astrophysicist was also in this
series. Let's hear a short clip from him as to
maybe why we don't want to understand or believe
this stuff. You know, for our whole lives
and our parents whole lives since the 1940s,
we've been told by authorities and scientists
that this is ridiculous, that this is nonsense.
And I think that's the main reason why you don't have many serious or until recently,
you've had very few serious scientists studying this. I would say there's probably
on the order of 15 experts in the world. That
to me is shocking and it suggests that there's
something maybe deeper than the stigma and all
of the obvious things that are preventing people
from studying this, that maybe people don't want
to know what this phenomena is. Maybe people don't
want to know the truth. Maybe it scares them
a little bit somehow. So Matthew, maybe this
scares people somehow. We've kind of talked
about that, but let's maybe segue into your story
because maybe there's a good reason to be scared.
You know, there is. I mean, and some people have
thrown around this word sober if they were
to have to describe the phenomenon or somber.
And it really is kind of sombering because when
you start to have these follow-on experiences,
right? The hitchhiker effect, as they call it, where something follows you home,
it's just so immediately disruptive and disturbing to suddenly be faced with this
in your home, in your bedroom at night, being
woken up and you're seeing non-human intelligences
there. Now, let's just step back a half step here
for just a second because Jeffrey Mishlove has
interviewed lots of folks who have had these
experiences. Heck, he interviewed John Mack in
the 1990s and Jacques Vallée and others. But let's
describe what the hitchhiker experience is. Again,
even though Jeff has described it on this channel,
that this is when people sometimes have a close
encounter or are exposed to what you were exposed to,
with the Gimbal event. Sometimes they find themselves
in that same situation and there's an energy,
there's a consciousness, there may be a being
that follows them. That's why we use the term hitchhiker, correct?
Yes, that's correct. And I think what happens is just that it's like,
you know, the event will happen. Several people
or in some cases hundreds or thousands of people
may witness this, but it will strike certain
people a certain way. And I don't know how they
do it, but somehow they pick up on that, right?
And it's almost, I describe it as like running
a magnet over a table filled with different
kinds of metals. And some of those metals will
be magnetized, some of them won't. But you know,
running the magnet over that, you'll see which
ones react, you know? And so I think that these
incidences are very similar to that in that respect.
Describe some of them for us, Matthew. I have read your book, Initiated, and again,
it's a very honest book. Some of it's quite chilling, but describe some of the events
and what you experienced.
Yeah, well, I mean, the first event that
happened, I had an entity in my room. One night,
I woke up because something grabbed my arm. And I
woke up, I thought, well, my room is going blurry
for some reason. So I went to try to raise my
hands to my face and kind of wipe the sleep out
of my eyes. And I couldn't move. I realized
I could not move. And then I woke up because
someone was grabbing my arm. So I, you know,
fought to kind of turn my head to the right to
see who was standing there. And I just saw this
shadow of a torso, two arms and a head kind of
bending over, looking at me. And as I'm
looking at this, the behind this shadow figure,
there was this golden light just started to light up my room. And then it became very
bright golden light. And the light concentrated
into rays of light coming out of its head.
And I thought to myself, what is going on? You
know, this was just, you don't expect to wake
up in the middle of night and see something like
that. And then, you know, after that, I kind of
lost consciousness and fell asleep. And then there
was a sexual experience. And I could see that this
female who was there had blue skin. It was, I, my
hands were on her thighs and I could feel her skin
and it was not like normal human skin. It was much thicker than human skin would be.
And then I woke up the next morning and I was just, I felt like I wanted to throw up,
and I was just, I felt like I wanted to
throw up. You know, I was, I was like, what,
what was that? Well, you felt that you were assaulted.
Yeah, I did. I felt totally, completely violated.
And, but you know, what kind of pulled me back
from that feeling of violation was the fact that
there was this whole light show associated with
it. And I started to think to myself, well, that
looks like religious art that I've seen from all
over the world, right? The rays of gold coming
out of the divine entity's head or, or the light
behind some divine figure. And I thought to myself,
there's, there's, there's a lot more going on here
than I currently understand. I'm obviously not the
first one to see this because it's in religious
art all over the world. And so, you know, that
kind of pulled me back and, and kept me from
jumping to conclusions throughout the experience,
which I think is something that people
have a problem with, right? Something like this
happens to you and you want to just jump to,
oh my gosh, it's evil. This is, this is an evil
thing. This can't be happening. I need to be
afraid of this, so on and so forth. But, or, or
maybe they, the first step is they'd want to take
you to a psychiatrist to make sure that you were
drugged properly. Yes. That would be the first
step. And then the second step is not to believe
you. And maybe the third step is, oh my God,
this is happening and I don't want to think about
it. That's right. And you know, I, that was, that
was my immediate thought too, was that, you know,
this was happening to me and, and what was worse
about it was that I couldn't tell, I was like,
well, who am I even going to tell about this?
If I tell anybody about this, I'm going to wind
up in a straight jacket. I'm going to lose my
clearance, you know, and I'll be out of a job and
this, this, this would ruin my life, you know?
So I had to just kind of sit with it and, and, and to just try to find some kind of
way to be okay with it. Um, which was not easy.
It was not actually forced you deeper. Again,
we talked a little bit about the fact that you
grew up in a kind of a secular atheistic household,
which is, I don't know what a raw sense of humor
they must've had because all of a sudden you're
starting to, to look at the yogis and initiates
and, uh, the Kybalion and other kinds of esoteric
literature that five years prior, you would never
even dream of, of reaching out and opening up and,
and, and reading. That's correct. I mean, I, you
know, when, when, before I had this experience
with this blue being in my room, I came across
this book in a very, um, terrifying, uh, and
paranormal way. And it was a book called the
Kybalion. And, and when I first read it one night,
uh, I, or read the synopsis of the book online, I thought, oh, you know, I'm not,
I'm not reading that. That's that just, that
is out there. Um, forget about it, you know?
Yeah. Uh, but it was the next day that I had this
set of just terrifying coincidences that just lined
up. And it was very obvious to me that the whole day was a construction just for me,
you know? And, and that to me did not fit my worldview, right? So the recurring line,
right? Is a recurring line in the Kybalion about there, there are no coincidences,
something along those lines. Yes, exactly. And,
and that was how the day wrapped up. I ended up
walking past this woman at a gas station, uh,
around midnight on a Thursday night near the
freeway. She's dressed to the nines sitting with a
homeless man, right? And I knew that this was out
of place. It shouldn't be happening. There's no
way a woman who's dressed like the women I work
with who are about to go brief Congress is
sitting here near the freeway at a gas station
with a homeless man eating, you know, at midnight.
Yeah. Uh, so I'm walking past them and, and then
this total set of just impossible coincidences
that led me to this gas station in the middle of
night. And this woman points at the homeless man
and she says, you see, there's no such thing as
coincidence. Everything happens for a reason. And
I thought no way to that woman just say that as I
was walking past, there's no way, you know? Um,
and so that, that I thought to myself as I entered
this, this 7-Eleven or Circle K, this convenience
store, I was like, well, that's what this book,
the Kybalion said. And so I guess I'm going to
be reading this book, you know, because there's
certainly more there than I, I realize, you know,
and it was, it was then that I read this book
several times and I thought, okay, well, I guess
maybe this is some kind of learning experience
for me. Let's, let's learn. I'm ready for more,
